title: Thursday, 23rd November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:03am

Hey. Hi. Hello. Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily etc.

BE11:04am

Here's a good one.

BE11:04am

11:05 am
BE11:05am

That's from The Defensive Value Investor: A complete step-by-step guide to building a high-yield, low-risk share portfolio

BE11:05am

£22.95 in paperback: https://www.amazon...book/dp/B01C36VOSU

BE11:07am

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Investing's bloody difficult, isn't it?

BE11:07am

I mean, Centrica was meant to be defensive.....

BE11:07am

... and it was already cheap.

11:07 am
Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 136.00, down 27.3 (-16.72%), High: 145.00, Low: 133.70, Volume: 59.83m
BE11:08am

Here's the first line of Kepler's morning note ....

BE11:08am

We upgraded Centrica to Buy last week

11:08 am
BE11:08am

.... which ain't too clever either.

BE11:09am

So anyway, we have an expected EPS at 12.5p for the year

BE11:10am

Partly on a 0.8p one-off, but numbers are weak as anything even ignoring that.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

UK is only just breaking even.

BE11:11am

Kepler, god bless'em, is still trying to sell the knife catching argument.

BE11:11am

All in all, and adjusting for the one-offs, we are broadly comfortable with our operating modelling. A potential net impact on valuation does not seem to exceed a few pence per share, and we consequently keep our 190p TP. EPS is not a good way of valuing a utility (we have not looked at EPS for nearly two decades), and it is EPS that seems to disappoint the most. It is also not relevant for the dividend, which is tied to cash flow (an increase is envisaged, underpinning a 12p DPS, which we model for the year). We see the current share price pressures as a buying opportunity. Fear and aversion to the stock is at an all-time high in the market, and the dividend yield on the 12p to be paid for this year is now above 8%. We assume a cut next year, but not to below 10p, which would still have the stock at 7%. If we go gloom and doom, the lowest thinkable yield would still be 5-6%. It does not feel good here with the entire market against the stock, but we think with a view to next year, taking this risk makes sense, and will prove rewarding.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Which is .......... I mean, what else are they going to argue.

BE11:13am

Because Kepler -- this very morning! -- published 263 pages on why Centrica is a buy.

BE11:13am

Two hundred and sixty three pages!

11:13 am
BE11:14am

I'm not kidding. Look:

BE11:14am

BE11:14am

Imagine putting out 263 pages on a single company on the day it has a profit warning. I mean .....

11:14 am
BE11:15am

.... there's unfortunate, and then there's Sideshow Bob with the rakes unfortunate.

BE11:15am

Anyway, let's head back into the detail of the warning.

BE11:15am

That 12.5p EPS compares to a 15.5p consensus.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

Barclays can summarise:

BE11:16am

This adjusted EPS number includes a one-off non cash 0.8p charge from the North American business. Stripping out this one off number, the adjusted EPS that the company is guiding towards remain 14% below Bloomberg consensus. The company is citing lower than expected adjusted operating profit in both the North American business and the UK business as the main reasons for the weak performance, together with the impact of the warmer weather in October and November. Current level of dividend per share is confirmed however as it is underpinned by the still solid operating CF generation (expected to be above £2bn for the FY) and contained net debt (expected in the guided range of £2.5-3bn for the FY). Bloomberg consensus is looking for a 12.1p dividend and £2.72bn net debt. The company continues to focus on its strategic transformation, repositioning the group towards more customer-facing activities and away from its assets business. All other aspects of the company’s 2017 guidance are reiterated.

BE11:16am

As can RBC.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Even after allowing for the 0.8p/sh one-off charge in North America Business this statement shows a very difficult operating environment for CNA. The market will be concerned that there will be sustainably lower profit from CNA Business in both the UK and the US, and the scale of customer losses in the residential market in the UK is alarming (even if these were less profitable customers).

BE11:17am

Key Highlights
l
In Centrica Consumer, efficiencies are offsetting overall gross margin decline. Energy supply accounts have continued to fall with CNA losing
an eye watering 823k customers since half year, and services customers are down by 39k. But growth in Connected Home continues with the
number of Hive hubs installed now at 750k and up 42% since the start of the year. Cumulative Hive product sales is now at 1.2m, and it may be
tough for CNA to hit the annual target of 1.5m. Overall, 2017 EBIT expected to be broadly in line with 2016.
l
In Centrica Business, there has been significant market pressures in North America Business with highly competitive market conditions. There
is also a one-off non-cash charge of £46m relating to a reassessment of the historic recognition of unbilled power revenues. North America
Business is expected to report full year adjusted operating profit of ~£80m (versus RBCe £250m, pre one-off). The UK Business is also facing
competitive pressures and CNA now expect the business to be broadly break-even in 2017 (versus RBCe of £45m).
l
In Asset businesses, higher commodity prices have been beneficial for unhedged volumes. CNA expect H2 2017 E&P adjusted operating profit
to be similar to H1 2017. In Centrica Storage, cushion gas production from the Rough asset has been stronger than expected and therefore the
business is now expected to be profitable in H2 2017 and close to break even for the full year.
l
Group net finance charge and tax rate, 2017 net finance charge is expected to be ~£350m, consistent with the H1 2017 run rate. The 2017 full
year effective tax rate is expected to be 26%. In 2018, the effective tax rate is expected to return to a higher level.

BE11:19am

Okay, so there's a 2017 reassurance.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

But 2018 divi looks seriously in doubt, no?

BE11:20am

Management say they "would be willing to operate with dividend cover from earnings below historic levels" but, really, denial isn't a solution to anything.

BE11:20am

Anyway, sector.

11:20 am
National Grid PLC (NG.:LSE): Last: 862.20, down 29.1 (-3.26%), High: 872.30, Low: 859.50, Volume: 3.31m
SSE PLC (SSE:LSE): Last: 1,330, down 37 (-2.71%), High: 1,363, Low: 1,325, Volume: 2.21m
Severn Trent PLC (SVT:LSE): Last: 2,105, down 18 (-0.85%), High: 2,219, Low: 2,088, Volume: 519.01k
11:21 am
United Utilities Group PLC (UU.:LSE): Last: 780.50, down 2 (-0.26%), High: 786.50, Low: 776.00, Volume: 1.08m
BE11:21am

(@GBKrona: by memory, I think insurance is where the biggest yielders are now. Make of that what you will.)

undefined
11:22 am
BE11:23am

Oh, stould have said National Grid up there is ex div.

BE11:23am

Anyway, what else do we have this morning?

BE11:24am

(@Google: no clue, sorry.)

11:24 am
BE11:24am

M&B mentioned, since we're in warning territory.

Mitchells & Butlers PLC (MAB:LSE): Last: 239.00, down 19 (-7.36%), High: 255.00, Low: 221.40, Volume: 932.09k
BE11:25am

Interim dividend dropped

11:25 am
BE11:25am

"pending assessment" of capital allocation prospects.

BE11:25am

And it's not entirely clear why.

BE11:26am

Current trading's fine.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Adjusted PBT of £183m is ahead of consensus.

BE11:26am

(Okay, only marginally. Consensus was £180m. But still.)

BE11:27am

Sales slightly weak over the past month or two, but hardly in crisis levels.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

EBIT margin drifts back from 15.2% to 14.4%, as expected.

BE11:28am

Story is mostly just the M&B story, which is about price hikes rather than volume.

BE11:29am

Food and drink sales up 1.4% and 2.1% respectively, even though food and drink volumes were down 2% and 4% respectively, which you can say is a model working quite well.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

And yet, no divi.

BE11:30am

What to read into that? Well, the obvious conclusion is that they're short of cash. Numis:

BE11:30am

It suggests that cash is the main constraint: for FY18 we forecast £29m of FCF prior to £82m of scheduled bond amortisation. This suggests that if the board is reluctant to see an increase in MAB's short term debt (£150m facility currently "marginally drawn") a dividend payment is
unlikely.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Sorry, haven't really prepared much for today because I was working through my reading list.

BE11:31am

And Citi.

BE11:31am

We expect little change to consensus forecasts at this stage. We expect the shares will be weak on news that the interim dividend will not be paid in FY18 as the group weighs up the cash calls on the business, notably the £200m pa capex plan as well as mandatory bond amortization (FY18E £82m) and pension recovery payments of £46m pa. We think this also reflects the very uncertain economic environment but also points to the group’s weak balance sheet and desire not to draw down short term debt facilities. The amount of final dividend will be assessed at the year end.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

(@doeswalk: I'd be rather surprised if M&B went for a cash acquisition, and even more surprised if it went for a rights issue given its rather complicated shareholder base.)

BE11:32am

Valuation & View — Sell. We think FY18E c9x PE and c8x EV/EBITDA are misleading as they fail to take account of very real cash drains on the business, including the c£200m pa capex needs plan and ongoing pension recovery payments of at least £46m pa following the triennial pension review. As a result we see a FCF yield of only 2% compared to peers of c7%.

BE11:33am

May as well do sector again, right?

11:33 am
Greene King PLC (GNK:LSE): Last: 505.00, down 13 (-2.51%), High: 518.00, Low: 490.20, Volume: 704.89k
Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 285.80, down 6.2 (-2.12%), High: 293.70, Low: 284.70, Volume: 372.12k
Marston's PLC (MARS:LSE): Last: 101.90, down 2.1 (-2.02%), High: 105.00, Low: 99.85, Volume: 1.66m
11:34 am
undefined
BE11:35am

Sould we mention the Budget? I'm not sure if the Budget has had enough coverage yet in the national press.

BE11:36am

A request that we ignore housebuilders. Pah! Likely.

11:37 am
Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 620.50, up 10.5 (+1.72%), High: 623.50, Low: 605.00, Volume: 4.20m
Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 3,734, up 77 (+2.11%), High: 3,747, Low: 3,626, Volume: 150.54k
Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 195.80, up 2.5 (+1.29%), High: 197.40, Low: 191.60, Volume: 8.37m
11:38 am
BE11:38am

We made the point, along with absolutely everyone else yesterday, that stamp duty cuts are inflationary to prices but do jack spit for volume.

BE11:39am

What spooked more was yet another landbanking review.

BE11:39am

Course, the sellside don't generally believe that landbanking happens.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Here's MOST.

BE11:40am

[T]he government has also highlighted the difference between planning permissions and housing starts - hinting at tightening up the rules here with a review to report on an interim basis by the time of its Spring budget statement. We think this may signal that the government is seeking to unblock the market here, ie moving towards a 'u se it or lose it' approach, in order to support volumes.

BE11:40am

Contrary to much of the housebuilding industry’s own messaging, most of the existing datasets (see Exhibit 1) suggest that it is not the planning system that is the reason for the low number of starts, with the gap between permissions and starts widening in recent years. To the extent that today's announcement could ultimately drive an uncontrolled increase in land-sales and/or completions (at the expense of price and developer profitability), we would see this as a negative for pricing at the margin, particularly for London, which the Chancellor highlighted as a particular problem ("In London alone, there are 270,000 residential planning permissions unbuilt"); however, we would hope that the increase in volumes that the broader sector could deliver should offset the impact at the earnings level.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Here's Exhibit 1. You might have to squint a bit.

BE11:41am

BE11:42am

As for Ibstock .... is there a dwngrade around? Haven't seen one.

11:42 am
Ibstock PLC (IBST:LSE): Last: 242.90, up 9.4 (+4.03%), High: 245.30, Low: 230.30, Volume: 773.25k
BE11:43am

(@Tom: aren't house prices to a large extent just a reflection of credit costs, and credit wasn't 1% APR in the 1960s? I'm not an expert, please note, because I don't go to enough dinner parties.)

undefined
11:45 am
BE11:46am

Telit? Really? Okay.

Telit Communications PLC (TCM:LSE): Last: 166.00, down 23 (-12.17%), High: 170.00, Low: 146.00, Volume: 2.93m
BE11:47am

So! Profit warning.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

To go along with the confirmation that the 888 chap is being dropped in.

BE11:47am

Earnings "materially below" previous

BE11:49am

Second warning, of course. Already cut to $44-48m from $47-60m in September.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

The more surprising news perhaps is that Yosi Fait
takes over as CEO

BE11:50am

You'll remember Mr Fait slotted a bunch of shares in July.

BE11:51am

As in, half a million immediately before Telit's H1 numbers.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Which is something the FCA's looking into

BE11:51am

But Telit, having asked its finest legals, has concluded that it's all fine. Nothing to worry about.

BE11:53am

The reason the shares aren't lower, I'd wager, is a kind of reverse Darwinism.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Everyone who was invested in Telit but who also had a firm grip of reality will have exited a long time ago.

BE11:54am

In the face of bad news, the folks who are left seem a more resilient bunch.

undefined
11:55 am
BE11:55am

What else will get us to midday?

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 152.90, up 4.1 (+2.76%), High: 153.30, Low: 149.10, Volume: 6.44m
BE11:55am

Morgan Stanley has been talking to the media buyers again, and the media buyers seem to be cheery.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Three's an entire thesis to be written about the bipolar moods of media buyers. Everything's either great or terrible, nothing inbetween. Anyway, here's the gist of it.

BE11:57am

Post Q3 (advertising down 4%) and a better than expected outlook for Q4 (+1% according to ITV; we had -5%, the most optimistic forecasts had -1.5%), we raise forecasts. This is the first upturn in forecast momentum since early 2016. Our 2017 NAR forecast rises from -6.5% to -5% and 2018 from -1% to +0.2% (stronger than expected end to 2017, easy comp, benefit of the World Cup, improving FMCG spend). Despite £15m of extra negative cost items in 2018, cleared out of the way by ITV, our EPS forecasts rise by 1-3% pa 2017-19.

BE11:57am

Why we are positive: (i) Advertising is on a positive trend (Q1 2017 -9%, Q2 -7%, Q3 -4%, Q4+1%). (ii) 2018 should start well. We have Q1 NAR up 1% and Q2 up 5%. (iii) ITV suggested that key categories FMCG and grocer advertising (35% of total), are turning up. (iv) Good audience performances (ITV total impacts up 2% in 2016 and flat ytd in 2017) suggest no impetus to raise underlying programming spend from c£1bn, even after the new CEO arrives. (v) Discussions with the chairman suggest the new CEO is likely to ‘refresh’ rather than fundamentally change ITV – we suspect more emphasis on acquisitions rather than special dividends. (vi) Studios saw 9% organic revenue growth in Q3 2017 and looks in good shape into 2018. (vii) We think negotiation of retransmission fees with Virgin could be worth an incremental c£30m pa, a high quality stream of recurring earnings, and c4% incremental to ITV pre-tax in 2018. Some suggest ITV is looking for nearer £80m pa (Daily Telegraph, 6 Nov, unconfirmed). A 9.9% shareholder who "would love" to own ITV, although not at the then current price (John Malone, FT, 11 May – price was c190p) provides constant interest.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Structural debates, but too lowly rated: We think the UK commercial TV model is resilient, the combination of ITV NAR ( +0.8%) and online, pay and interactive revenues (+21% pa) have jointly grown 2.5% pa 2011-17e, and ITV has an online presence with millennials. 75% of the UK's 16-24 year olds are registered with the ITV Hub. At 150p, ITV trades at a sub 10x P/E in 2018 (9.7x), dropping to 8.5x by 2020. The FCF yield is 8.2% in 2017, and the dividend yield is 5.0%. ITV is trading at its lowest P/E multiple both absolute and relative to the market for the last decade. Our DCF requires a WACC of 10% and 0.3% terminal growth to get to the current share price. We use 8.5% and 2% to reach a 230p price target to put ITV on 15x 2018, the average p/e of the European broadcasters.

BE11:59am

Discussion on the right about who actually watches the adverts .....

BE11:59am

....... which has been around for as long as telly has, pretty much.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Though the same arguments can be made for digital, where the ground is much less familiar.

BE12:00pm

Which is why the whole "ITV provides event telly" argument is key to the buy case.

BE12:01pm

As in, you can fart about trying to sausage slice digital data to figure out how many Facebook are actually useful people. Or you can buy 20 seconds during I'm A Celebrity and your only real risk is that they'll be putting the kettle on when it runs.

12:01 pm
undefined
BE12:01pm

Anyway!

BE12:01pm

Looks like we've made it to midday.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Thanks for sticking with.

BE12:01pm

Back tomorrow for more of the same.

BE12:02pm

Afternoon all.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

MAB trades on a CY18 P/E of 8.0x, EV/EBITDA of 9.0x and FCF yield of 8% (the latter is pre-growth capex but post-£45m pension contribution). We are cautious on the outlook for M&B as we do not expect lfl sales to cover mounting cost headwinds and believe the risk of a dividend cut underlines the challenges facing managed pub groups.
